Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of A Versatile High Resolution MS System for Determination of Small Molecules of Environmental and Health Concern

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Reckhow, David A.
Proposal: 1428873
Title: MRI: Acquisition of A Versatile High Resolution MS System for Determination of Small Molecules of Environmental and Health Concern

Significance

This proposal is for the acquisition of a high resolution system for identifying and quantifying trace organic contaminants in water. The research group involved in this project has forged a strong link between environmental engineering and public health. Their proposed research projects have many applied objectives including potential translational benefits, such as discovery and then remediation of emerging contaminants in drinking water, and novel treatments for water and sanitation in Third World countries. The Xevo G2-S QTof is ideally suited for use by students from broad backgrounds due to its simple and intuitive interface. This instrument will be a centerpiece of an open resource (EEAP) available not only to those at UMass, but across the Northeast region. At UMass, it will serve the core researchers in Environmental Engineering, as well as an interdisciplinary group of researchers in various science disciplines and Public Health. Outside of UMass, it will be available for use by researchers in the 5-college consortium, and beyond, especially Universities and Colleges in New England and nearby states.

Technical Description

This proposal is for the acquisition of a high resolution system for identifying and quantifying trace organic contaminants in water. The Xevo G2-S QTof is a quadrupole time-of-flight instrument capable of rapidly switching between liquid (e.g., UPLC) and gas (e.g., GC) sources. This instrument will be a centerpiece of an open resource (EEAP) available not only to those at UMass, but across the Northeast region. This instrument will help connect engineering management and control technologies to the ultimate endpoints of public health. Examples include the role of watershed management and treatment technologies on bladder cancer caused by halobenzoqinones and related compounds in drinking water. Another touches upon the role of elevated bromide from industrial activities on cancer. A third pertains to nitrogenous organic compounds generated in surface waters from algal activity and photonitration reactions and human health endpoints. Others employ innovative mixed algal-bacterial granules to treat wastewater and produce biofuel, or bioelectrical systems to facilitate wastewater treatment in modern non-flush systems while producing electricity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic compounds of concern to human and ecological health are increasingly found in natural water (rivers, lakes, rain), public drinking water and municipal or industrial wastewater.  Many of these are difficult to detect by conventional methods, a fact that limits our ability to protect the public and preserve environmental quality.

Research at the University of Massachusetts (Amherst) have long been leaders in identifying and controlling harmful chemical contaminants in water.  This grant was intended to give UMass researchers a new set of tools to improve and add value to their research efforts.

The centerpiece of this grant is a newly purchased instrument that can measure organic compounds in water at unprecedented sensitivity and accuracy.  The instrument is a Xevo G2-XS quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometer with both gas and liquid chromatographic inlets.  Generically, this type of instrument is referred to as both a liquid chromatograph – mass spectrometer (LC/MS) and a gas chromatograph – mass spectrometer (GC/MS).  It differs from most LC/MS and GC/MS instruments in its mass resolution, sensitivity and its ability to analyze organic compounds with a wide range of polarity and volatility.

The instrument has been incorporated into a wide range of research projects at UMass.  In most cases it has allowed us to substantially expand our activities and added real value to the work.  In several cases it has been integrated into research proposals.  Nearly all of the projects below are interdisciplinary.  In most cases the work involves members of the environmental engineering group, public health, soil science and others.

  1. Transformations of compounds expected from accidental discharges of crude oil in drinking water reservoirs
  2. N-chloro-haloacetamides, a new class of hazardous contaminants in drinking water
  3. Investigation of carbohydrates in Algal Granules used to treat wastewater
  4. Halobenzoquinones and their degradation products (see figure 1)
  5. Impacts of biological nitrification-denitrification on control of NDMA in drinking water
  6. Pharmaceuticals and related compounds from toothpaste
  7. Genetic variability and chemical phenotypes of henbane
  8. Oxidation of perfluorinated contaminants in water with reactive oxygen species
  9. Electrochemical removal of 1,4-dioxane from drinking water
  10. Characterization of Natural Organic Matter in water
  11. Use of urine for amending compost in community gardens
  12. Toxic nitrogenous organic compounds in water (see figure 2)

 

Broader Impacts

Aside from supporting new avenues of investigation in research originated at UMass, the new Xevo instrument also has added to UMass’s capabilities and the services that it offers to outside parties.  These advanced testing and piloting services add value to treatment technologies developed by US companies who use our services.  We have been actively offering our full suite of piloting and analytical services and as a result we are better able to fill a need in the water sector community.  Our collaboration with the water cluster in New England (NEWIN) has been a mutually beneficial endeavor in this area.

The Xevo QTof has already served as a catalyst for interdisciplinary research and general collaboration on the UMass campus (e.g., note the many interdisciplinary projects in the list above).  This brings multiple benefits.  It adds value to each research project, but perhaps more importantly, it gives the student researchers a broader perspective on the problems they’re studying.

Other benefits include outreach to the community and to undergraduate populations.  A prime example is the urine amended compost project.  This project is being conducted in collaboration with local community leaders.  In addition, it is being done with the primary participation of undergraduate students at UMass.  Other projects are similarly engaging undergraduates, many of whom are underrepresented minorities.  Our hope is that these studies will further stimulate interest in environmental research and attract talented students to work in this area.
